Tardigrade Biogeography
Chapter
  • Jan 2018
  • Sandra J. McInnes
  • P. J. A. Pugh
We report on the history and the progress made towards understanding tardigrade biogeography. We have updated our data and provided new analyses of both limno-terrestrial and marine tardigrade faunas to show the limitations of the earlier techniques, demonstrated newer ideas and highlighted the regions requiring further study.

Tardigrades from Signy Island, South Orkney Islands, with particular reference to freshwater species
Article
  • Nov 1995
  • Sandra J. McInnes
Seventeen species of Tardigrada from lakes and catchments on Signy Island, South Orkney Islands, are described. Two species, Echiniscus punctus and Isohypsibius laevis are new to science, and two, Oreella minor and Pseudechiniscus suillus , are new to the Signy Is. records.

Projects

Projects (3)
Bird-Bryophyte Interactions in Sub-Antarctic Chile
Project
This research addresses the importance of bryophytes in the diet of birds in the Sub-Antarctic Magellanic Ecoregion of Chile, and the potential for birds to disperse bryophytes.
View
Annotated zoogeography of non-marine Tardigrada
Project
The aim of the project is to summarise and review all literature records of limno-terrestrial water bears (Tardigrada). We have been publishing the results in a series of Zootaxa monographs. Each part describes an updated and revised tardigrade taxonomy that is accompanied by geographic co-ordinates, habitat, and biogeographic comments for a given geographic region (typically a continent). It is hoped this work will serve as a reference point and background for further zoogeographical and taxonomical studies.
